Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: CSHL NSF-REU Bioinformatics and Computational Neuroscience Summer Undergraduate Program
Award.AbstractNarration:
This REU Site award to Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory (CSHL), located in Cold Spring Harbor, NY, will support the training of ten students for ten weeks during the summers of 2016-2018. This award is supported by the Division of Biological Infrastructure in the Directorate for Biological Sciences (BIO) and the Division for Mathematical Sciences in the Directorate for Mathematics and Physical Sciences (MPS).CSHL's REU in Bioinformatics and Computational Neuroscience (BCN) provides participants with an exceptional research experience, integrating genomics and neuroscience through shared analysis tools. Spanning genomes, cells, organisms and the brain, the program trains students to approach complex biological systems quantitatively. Students conduct full-time, independent research under the mentorship of one of CSHL's approximately 50 faculty members working in genomics, quantitative biology, and neuroscience. Participants have access to state-of-the-art technologies, such as high-throughput sequencing and two-photon imaging, and attend lab meetings and research seminars. The REU curriculum includes workshops on quantitative techniques, responsible conduct of research, scientific communication, and scientific careers. The REU culminates with a symposium in which participants present their work to CSHL's scientific community. Students are housed on CSHL's 110-acre campus, within walking distance of laboratories and dining halls. Participants receive room and board and a summer stipend and have access to campus amenities. Students apply online, supplying a personal statement, two letters of recommendation, and academic records. REU participants are selected based on academics, motivation, and demonstrated potential.

It is anticipated that 30 students, primarily from schools with limited research opportunities or those from underrepresented groups, will be trained in CSHL's REU in BCN. Participants will learn to interrogate biological questions with computational tools and techniques. Through the 10-week REU experience, participants will learn how research is conducted. Many will present the results of their work at national scientific conferences, furthering their identity as independent scientists.

A common web-based assessment tool used by all REU programs funded by the Division of Biological Infrastructure (Directorate for Biological Sciences) is used to determine the effectiveness of the training program. Students are tracked after the program to determine career paths. Students will be asked to respond to an automatic email sent via the NSF reporting system. More information about the program is available by visiting http://www.cshl.edu/Education/NSF-REU-in-Bioinformatics-and-Computational-Neuroscience.html, or by contacting the PI (Dr. Anne Churchland, churchland@cshl.edu), the co-PI (Dr. Michael Schatz, mschatz@cshl.edu).

POR.DRECONTENT:
The REU in Bioinformatics and Computational Neuroscience (BCN) at Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory (CSHL) is a 10-week program that is an integral part of the long-standing summer Undergraduate Research Program. The CSHL REU provides motivated undergraduate students an opportunity for first-hand experience in a research project under the mentorship of a CSHL faculty member, and to develop quantitative and computational skills from genomics to neuroscience. The students additionally attend lectures and workshops on biology, quantitative techniques, ethics, and careers in science.

After participating in the program, students are instilled with an appreciation of how quantitative tools can benefit numerous areas of biological research, especially genomics and neuroscience. From the bioinformatics and computational biology lectures, students are exposed to the theory behind widely used quantitative tools and are instructed in how to apply these tools. This curriculum gives many students their first exposure to quantitative biology, opening this significant area of research to these future scientists early in their careers. After completing the program, all participants have an increased level of knowledge of the basic concepts and appreciation for bioinformatics research and tools, while most gain a competency to deal with analytical or computational research questions and plan on pursuing further training in quantitative biology. REU students also gain an appreciation for how science impacts society through discussions of ethical practices of research and its implications for the public. The CSHL Meetings and Courses program provides REU students with a unique opportunity to attend lectures, and network with the more than 10,000 internationally renowned scientists who visit. During their time at CSHL, REU students are immersed in the Laboratory community through program and Laboratory events which promote peer communication, networking, and interactions that last beyond the summer.

Outcomes of the CSHL REU program include co-authorship from the participants on publications in peer-reviewed journals, and presentations at national scientific conferences. A significant number of recent REU students have also been awarded NSF Graduate Research Fellowships to support their studies, while others received an honorable mention. The broader impacts of the program include instruction in bioinformatics and computational biology that students underrepresented in these fields receive. The availability on a dedicated program website of teaching materials on bioinformatics and computational biology used in the programming workshops aids the wider scientific community as well. Thus, the CSHL REU program provides a valuable template for other academic institutions to incorporate BCN into their own academic programs.
